title: Lessons Learned in Building Linked Data for the American Art Collaborative

author: Craig A. Knoblock, Information Sciences Institute (ISI), University of Southern California

segmentation: OK, good morning everyone.
So I'm going to be talking about this work we did with a number of museums and that element talks lessons learned in building linked data for the American Art Collaborative.
And as you see, there are quite a few collaborates here.

Many of these are from USC, including a number of students that work in this project, but also so many of these authors are actually participants from the various museums that were involved in the project.
OK, so the project goal was to launch this American Art Collaborative, which is this consortium of 14 American art museums and the goal of the project was to explore the use of link data.
To make the museum data available for other people, to do research with education and outreach for the museums.
And really, there's a tremendous amount of interest from the Cultural Heritage community, especially from the museum and library communities.

In terms of exploiting Link data as a means of actually making their data available there very excited about it, and you know, there's quite a bit of momentum to actually do this, so we participated and helped form this consortium to essentially build this high quality link data.
So we wanted to create.
Which is called 5 star link data for the museums and this involved mapping the data about the artwork.

An artist to some common ontology linking the data to other resources and then you know it's sort of a medical which is creating and extending the tools to support this construction of data to make it as easy as possible to be able to create link data datasets and then finally to be able to create applications on top of the data to do interesting things with.
OK, so here's the outline.
My talk.
I'm going to 1st talk about the process of X.
Mapping the data, then linking the entities and finally using the link data, and I'll conclude with some related work and discussion.
Alright, so first mapping the data so it's worth noting that this was probably the most challenging part of the project.
This had to do with the fact that the museums had data in wildly different formats.
They each have their own collection management systems.

They were very limited in terms of what forms they could produce the data in, so we had a huge range of data both in terms of the type of information, the structure of the information, and even the underlying schema that they were using to publish it.

The second part of the challenge was that in the Cultural Heritage community, there's a, you know, a strong push to use the this ontology, called the See Docs, ERM Ontology which has evolved over the years, and there's been a tremendous amount of work put into this ontology to make it very comprehensive, and as a result, it's a very large and very complicated ontology, and we had a number of psyduck serum experts actually involved in this project working with us, which perhaps made the challenge even more complicated for us.
So in our approach to addressing this overall problem was first we had to deal with just a tremendous amount of data from the museums and a large number of sort of mappings of this data.
So we decided early on to use GitHub to basic organize all of this data.

That turned out to be a very wise choice, and as many of you know, we've been working on a tool over the years called Karma that is very good at sort of taking datasets and mapping them to a demand intelligent generating this set of mappings for that data, which is exactly we needed to do here.

So we use karma to create the mappings for each of the datasets and then finally, since this is a rather large project and we didn't necessarily have time to do this ourselves, we trained a team of USC students to basically take these tools and apply them.
Well, actually both build and apply the different tools to actually create these datasets.
So so the first thing was.
You know, applying karma to use this so.
I'm already existent amount of work to before this project, but this project really was a great sort of use case for us to really push on the technology and stuff.

Yeah, but what karma does for you is it essentially allows you to load in each of the datasets.

In any of these different formats that we had to work with and then allows you to interactively essentially do the mapping of the data to this domain ontology and one of the key things here is that Karma uses some machine learning tools under the hood to essentially make this mapping process as easy and simple as possible, and essentially tries to automate the process as you go, and in this process you know in this project we basically extended karma in several ways.
One was we.

Made it more interactive so you probably can't see, but all these little red dots there are things you can actually click on in the modeling process to sort of allow the user to visually interactively model the data, and karma is always making recommendations in each of these steps in the process.

And the other thing we did in this in this project was essentially to extend Karma to automatically publish all of the data directly into GitHub, which turned out to be very useful since it was a lot of data in a lot of models or mappings that we had to publish.

Statistics and actually the process of doing this.

So this is a list of all the museums, so there's actually 13 museums listed here because one museum it already mapped their own data, and on these 13 museums you can see all the different formats that were used here.
The number of files that they provided in these were actually just the files that we actually map.
There were some files that we didn't actually use in this project.
The important thing to note here is the number of mappings that were created.
So this is actually 99 different mappings that were created for all these museums, which is quite a bit of work, especially when you consider sort of the complexity of these models here.
And and the other thing to note here is in GitHub you can track the number of commits, how many change, update time to update the models and stuff, and you can see here there were 4636 commits.
That means you know each time someone changed the model and updated it.

So this is a you know a long process and and one of the reasons for that was sort of something we learned in the in the process of the project, which is that it's very hard for a group of individuals that even working with the same very well defined ontology to actually get the mappings done in a consistent way.
And so we went through a long process here.

It's described in the paper where we really ended up mapping some of the data three times to actually end up with the computer mapping and and that sort of led to the next slide in one of the lessons, which was that we.
Creating a set of target mappings.
So instead of just sort of saying OK, here's the ontology mapping data intelligence.
You figure how to use it.
The idea was actually defined a specific sort of way of actually mapping the data with a specific schema that describes exactly how some piece of information gets mapped.
So this is the target mapping for the classification of a piece of art.
You can see the mapping is, you know, not.

Not simple, but once once we moved to this model, so the first 2 iterations of this we essentially would generate the models, then we get all this feedback and the experts would debate whether or not it was the right mapping or not.
Even the experts wouldn't always agree on which way to map the data, so the target mapping was a huge innovation here and then.
One of the things this is built into a tool where it shows you the target mapping and then on the left side.
Here it has a set of queries that actually run against the data.
Once you've mapped the data.

Which is incredibly useful because what it means that if you map the data with respect to the target mapping and you run the query that's associated with the target mapping, then it'll show show you the actually results here.

So this is the result of the query and there's a button here where you could actually click and it will show you the query that it's running and over here on this side or all the different queries you can run for the on top of the data.
And this is a great innovation because it meant that someone who's actually making the data could first look at the target mapping.
Say OK, this is how we need to map the data could actually do the mapping of the data, then run load the data into the Triple Store, run a set of queries that would then verify that.
If they done it right, it will actually generate the data.

For example, how many transformations on the data do we have to do in karma?
Include you know creating your eyes, but often include many things like data cleaning operations where you had to sort of clean up the data.

Here we have the number of classes for each of the different museums, the number of types and number of links, and you can see the numbers at the bottom.
There's quite a bit of work here in terms of mapping all this data.
It's.

Here are some statistics on actually what was mapped, so in terms of the total number of constituents, which essentially the artists and then the people appear in the art, there was 52,000 across all the 13 museums here.
153 thousand objects, 325 thousand events, so an event would be something like OK.
This artist was born on this particular date.
Then we also had the places, which is, you know, locations where people are born or died or worked.
And then finally we generated close to 10,000,000 triples.
As part of this project so you can see there's a lot of data that came out of this.
OK, So what were some of the lessons that we learn?

Here, so the first one was that we wanted we really found it extremely useful to design the system in such a way that there were reproducible workflows, meaning that you allow the museums to export the raw data in whatever format they wanted to export the raw data, and this is very useful because they kept having to iterate and generate new datasets, right?
We discovered that oh, they didn't give us this data set or there was some other piece of information missing, or any variety of reasons.
So we went through multiple iterations and so having a reproducible workflow is extremely useful.
Second, was this using the shared repository for the data, so I'll play.

Using GitHub essentially as this place where the museums would actually publish their data, and then we would publish the results of all the work that we did back into the GitHub so that everyone could actually see it, and so you can go there and actually look at that.
And that turned out to be extremely effective way to organize.
You know when you essentially had 99 mappings for the different datasets.
Third one was that you know data cleaning was a huge significant part of the effort and is part of Karma.
You're able to actually include these operations directly into the workflows so that it's essentially documented and is part of something that is repeatable.
So that worked out extremely well.
The 4th one, and I think this probably was perhaps the most important lesson one we didn't start with and probably spent a year on the project that could have been considerably reduced.

Which was, you know, dealing with these mapping inconsistencies and, you know in this I think is a really important point, because it turns out that even though it may appear that the ontology is extremely well defined and everyone should be able to agree on how the data is mapped, that often is not the case, and so having this validation tool that essentially provides sort of the target mappings in a way to actually then run the queries against the data to verify the target mappings done.
Was a huge time saving in terms of doing it in the project.
You know, we once we figured out that OK, we need to use these target mappings.
We got a group of six or seven students together for about 2 weeks and they basically re mapped all the data.

You know project that we have been doing for a year and then finally that you know it's not completely solved when you have these target mappings 'cause there's still these small sort of subtle differences in terms of the mapping process and so it turned out that an expert review of the data was extremely useful.
I actually resisted this, 'cause I knew would be more work, but then when they did it I said, well, this is really important because.
There were several things about you know which field they actually used to create a urri because you know that's not a field that would actually maintain stable.
Some things you know that that you just need to know both about maybe the ontology and perhaps the domain that was extremely effective.
OK, the second step was actually.
King the data.

So here the goal was to essentially link the entities in the museums to other resources, and we wanted to create the capability for the museums to actually be able to curate the automatically generated links, because unlike many other sort of data sets out there that people have published in the museums really really care that the data that they publish is correct.
So as a demonstration of this, we took all of the artists across all the museums and essentially link them to the Getty You Land, which is the Getty List of artist names.
And and this actually in doing this I mean first we tried to use some of the existing tools and there were two problems that came up.

One was either they wouldn't scale because we're linking to data sets were extremely large, or the second problem was that they were just really complicated to use and students had a hard time getting them to configure.
Getting them properly configured.
So we ended up writing specialized scripts, asensi generate links that had high precision and recall, and this is important because the the museums were going to actually cure rate all of the links.
And to do that we built a nice review tool that made it very easy for them to sort of visualize the information.

Are artists or the people depicted in the artwork previously?

OK, So what were the lessons learn?

Unlinking first linking tools, and we actually found and spent a fair amount of time trying to use existing tools and stuff, and we found that they didn't scale well in many cases, or they were really complicated and so one of the lessons was that we needed better tools to be able to very quickly build these kinds of initial sort of sets of links, and that's actually something we're working on now.
Second one was the manual review.
I was actually somewhat surprised and pleased that the museums were actually willing to invest so much time, and actually this manual review process.
So they spent.
I mean, they reviewed 25,000 links.
I mean, they looked at everyone of those links.
Many of the museums said they took them a couple weeks of, you know, someone working full time at that task to actually do this, and you know we had some numbers in the paper.
I think it took between 18 and 53 seconds or something.
Review each link so it was pretty fast.
It's just there's a lot to review.

So we wanted we wanted very high precision high recall.

Here, so the first one was that we wanted we really found it extremely useful to design the system in such a way that there were reproducible workflows, meaning that you allow the museums to export the raw data in whatever format they wanted to export the raw data, and this is very useful because they kept having to iterate and generate new datasets, right?
We discovered that oh, they didn't give us this data set or there was some other piece of information missing, or any variety of reasons.
So we went through multiple iterations and so having a reproducible workflow is extremely useful.
Second, was this using the shared repository for the data, so I'll play.

Using GitHub essentially as this place where the museums would actually publish their data, and then we would publish the results of all the work that we did back into the GitHub so that everyone could actually see it, and so you can go there and actually look at that.
And that turned out to be extremely effective way to organize.
You know when you essentially had 99 mappings for the different datasets.
Third one was that you know data cleaning was a huge significant part of the effort and is part of Karma.
You're able to actually include these operations directly into the workflows so that it's essentially documented and is part of something that is repeatable.
So that worked out extremely well.
The 4th one, and I think this probably was perhaps the most important lesson one we didn't start with and probably spent a year on the project that could have been considerably reduced.

Which was, you know, dealing with these mapping inconsistencies and, you know in this I think is a really important point, because it turns out that even though it may appear that the ontology is extremely well defined and everyone should be able to agree on how the data is mapped, that often is not the case, and so having this validation tool that essentially provides sort of the target mappings in a way to actually then run the queries against the data to verify the target mappings done.
Was a huge time saving in terms of doing it in the project.
You know, we once we figured out that OK, we need to use these target mappings.
We got a group of six or seven students together for about 2 weeks and they basically re mapped all the data.

You know project that we have been doing for a year and then finally that you know it's not completely solved when you have these target mappings 'cause there's still these small sort of subtle differences in terms of the mapping process and so it turned out that an expert review of the data was extremely useful.
I actually resisted this, 'cause I knew would be more work, but then when they did it I said, well, this is really important because.
There were several things about you know which field they actually used to create a urri because you know that's not a field that would actually maintain stable.
Some things you know that that you just need to know both about maybe the ontology and perhaps the domain that was extremely effective.
